metadata.case_name: K. R. Deb v. Collector of Central Excise

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Sub Inspector of Central Excise in temporary vacancy on September 20, 1958 and reported for duty on October 15, 1958.
On May 30, 1959, appellant alleged to have detained five maunds of onion from house of Sayed Ahmad at Ramendranagar.
On May 31, 1959, Siddique Ahmad handed over Rs. 100 to appellant through Harendra Kumar Dutta, but appellant did not mention it in seizure report.
Charge framed by Collector R. C. Mehra: Appellant guilty of concealing realisation of Rs. 100 from Siddique Ahmad and not reporting it, thus misappropriating Govt. money.
Allegations supplied to appellant; he applied for copies of documents on December 28, 1960.
Appellant submitted written statement of defence on March 30, 1961 denying the charge.
Collector appointed B. P. Barua as Inquiry Officer on May 11, 1961.
Barua held inquiry and reported on July 3, 1961: No conclusive evidence of misappropriation; only concealment of seizure location from house shown as border, but charge did not include that.

Collector appointed R. K. P. Sinha as Inquiry Officer for supplementary open inquiry on August 22, 1961, as Barua did not record evidence of prosecution witnesses Harendra Kr. Dutta, Jagabandhu Patwari, Syed Ahmed, Siddique Ahmed.

Sinha reported on October 12, 1961: Nothing on record to prove acceptance of Rs. 100; Harendra Kumar Dutta did not appear despite summons; story topples; seizure in absence of Siddique Ahmed; episode cooked up.

Collector wrote to Sinha on December 20, 1961: Report sketchy, failed to appreciate evidence; direct to examine Harendra Kumar Dutta, Jagabandhu Patwari, Sepoy Monoranjan Ghosh; overwhelming evidence of corruption.
Sinha final report on January 20, 1962: No conclusive proof of acceptance of Rs. 100, but conduct of appellant may not be above board.
Collector ordered on February 13, 1962: Appoint new Inquiry Officer K. P. Patnaik for fresh inquiry into charge, in supersession of previous orders, under Rule 15(4) CCS CCA Rules 1957.
Patnaik reported on March 6, 1962: Proved that appellant did not bring Rs. 100 into account; misappropriated.
Show cause notice issued on March 15, 1962 why not dismissed.
Appellant applied for documents on March 20, 1962; gave explanation on May 21, 1962 asking personal hearing.
Appellant dismissed from service on June 4, 1962.
Appellant filed writ petition on June 14, 1962 under Art. 226.
Judicial Commissioner Court, Tripura dismissed writ petition on February 16, 1966.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Collector had authority to appoint a new Inquiry Officer for a fresh inquiry after two previous Inquiry Officers reported in favour of the appellant, and whether such successive inquiries are contemplated by Rule 15 of CCS (CCA) Rules, 1957.
Whether the order dated February 13, 1962 appointing fresh inquiry was mala fide.
Whether there was a proper inquiry as required, and breach of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Collector had no authority to appoint Shri K. P. Patnaik after Inquiry Officers reported in his favour; Rule 15 does not contemplate successive inquiries, nor setting aside earlier inquiries without reason.
Order dated February 13, 1962 was mala fide.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 15 provides for one inquiry; possible to ask for further evidence if defect, but no provision for completely setting aside previous inquiries because report does not appeal to Disciplinary Authority; Authority can reconsider evidence itself under Rule 9.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules do not contemplate action like Collector's on Feb 13, 1962; Collector avoided responsibility, determined to get report against appellant; procedure not warranted, harassing.

court_reasoning.text: Suspicion arises that Collector was determined to get some Inquiry Officer to report against appellant; no proper inquiry conducted, breach of Art. 311(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Material on record raises suspicion of prejudice.

holdings.text: No proper inquiry held; breach of Art. 311(2); order of dismissal quashed; appellant treated as continuing in service with pay and allowances.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art. 226; requirement of proper inquiry under Art. 311(2)

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs disciplinary inquiry procedure; does not permit successive fresh inquiries or setting aside previous reports without reason

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order dated June 4, 1962 quashed; appellant declared continuing in service; entitled to pay and allowances for period out of office; costs to appellant in Supreme Court and Judicial Commissioner Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Reinstatement with back pay and allowances; costs awarded.
outcome.costs: Appellant to have costs here and in Judicial Commissioner Court.

key_quotes.text: "There is no conclusive evidence to establish the charge of misappropriation of Govt. money."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: First Inquiry Officer Barua's finding in appellant's favour

key_quotes.text: "Thus the entire story of handing over the money to Sri Harendra Kumar Dutta in the presence of the Sub-Inspector on 31-5-59 topples down."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Second Inquiry Officer Sinha's observation exonerating appellant

key_quotes.text: "Rule 15, on the face of it, really provides for one inquiry but it may be possible if ... some serious defect ... the Disciplinary Authority may ask the Inquiry Officer to record further evidence. But there is no provision ... for completely setting aside previous inquiries."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on limits of Rule 15

key_quotes.text: "It seems to us that the Collector, instead of taking responsibility himself, was determined to get some officer to report against the appellant. The procedure adopted was not only not warranted by the rules but was harassing to the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Finding of improper procedure and suspicion of bias
